item.title: WHOISCGA1
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
Cereals Growers Association (CGA) is a national non-profit member-based farmer organization incorporated in August 1996. Its main purpose is to bring together commercial cereal farmers to promote collective action for the sustained improvement of their farming enterprises and in addressing industry challenges in Kenya.

CGA works with industry stakeholders such as government bodies, agricultural input suppliers, financial institutions, insurance companies, output buyers, development partners, Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) and others to provide services to its members.

CGA is headquartered in Nairobi and is on a day to day basis run by a team of thirteen (13) office-based professionals and field extension officers distributed across twenty-four (24) counties where we are operational. These are found in all the main cereal growing regions of Kenya and serving about 150,000 household members. The team is led by a Chief Executive Officer who is appointed by a Board of Trustees.

item.title: HQ Staff
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
Anthony Kioko

Chief Executive Officer

Anthony Kioko is an East Africa Agribusiness expert with 20 years’ experience managing public – private sector engagement initiatives. An agronomist by training, his previous management positions were at Oil Crop Development Ltd (Unilever Kenya Ltd subsidiary then), East African Breweries Ltd (a Diageo Plc Company). He was a beneficiary of the 2017 USDA FAS Cochran Fellowship Program, on Agricultural Extension and Farmer Leadership. Anthony serves on several boards including the Seed Trade Association of Kenya (STAK), Agriculture Industry Network (AIN) and is a Council Member of the Agriculture Sector Network (ASNET). Anthony is also a member of several Technical Working Groups in the Agriculture Sector including the Joint Thematic Working Group of the Ministry of Agriculture Livestock Fisheries and Cooperatives (MOALF&C) and ASNET.

Fredrick Muma

FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION MANAGER

Fredrick oversees the finance and administration functions of accounting, financial management, human resources, administration and their strategic contribution to CGA’s work. He is a financial expert with over seven years of experience in auditing, financial management, grants management, project management and administration gained from the private non-governmental sectors. Fredrick is currently pursuing M. Sc. Finance (Finance and Investment) from the University of Nairobi; he holds a Bachelor of Economics and Finance degree from Kenyatta University and is a Certified Public Accountant (CPA-K) and an active member of the Institute of Certified Public Accountants of Kenya (ICPAK). Fredrick is also a Certified Financial Modeling and Valuation Analyst (FMVA) by the Corporate Finance Institute (CFI). Fredrick joined CGA in January 2014 prior to which he worked as an audit associate at the Crowe Horwarth EA Audit firm.

ALVIN OGOLLA

FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT

A result oriented individual, passionate about creating positive impact that matters in the society. With over 3yrs working experience, he assists in the administrative and financial roles in CGA. Alvin holds a Bachelor of Economics and Finance degree from Kenyatta University with training on Financial modelling and data analysis. He has previously worked with Kenya Association of Hotelkeepers & Caterers (KAHC), Tribe Hotel and Brocahoto Sacco Ltd.

Wight Ndambuki

project Accountant

Wight has working experience in financial and administrative support with bias in accounting functions. With over 3 years’ experience in finance and accounting on programme-based grants such as UN – World Food Programme, USAID, AGRA, FERT, RTI International, Australian High Commission -Kenya, AATF, Netherlands Space Office, Christian Aid, IFPRI and the Business Advocacy Fund. Wight has passion for numbers and skilled in financial accountability and reporting. Wight is at an advanced stage towards full professional training in Certified Public Accounting. Previously Wight has received training in Ethics and Communication at Strathmore University.

Violet Nyando

MEMBERSHIP, POLICY AND ADVOCACY MANAGER

Agricultural Innovation Expert with background training in Agricultural Rural Innovations Studies. With over 15 years of experience, Violet has expertise in the areas of Agricultural Innovations including Climate Smart Agriculture, Agricultural Policy Development, Institutional Development and Strengthening, Agricultural Advisory and Extension, Agricultural Product Value Chain Development, Gender Analysis and Mainstreaming, Governance and Leadership of Agri-Enterprises and Public Policy Lobby and Advocacy Processes. Violet is also skilled and facilitating public-private sector dialogue forums.

SAMUEL OSEBE

FIELD LOGISTICS SUPPORT MANAGER

Samuel Osebe is an experienced strategic project management and implementation expert with over 10 years’ progressive experience gained from working in various capacities. He has successfully supported multiple CGA projects, partners and stakeholders in their business linkage activities including trade fairs. Highly proficient in supply chain / logistics management.

ANSELM MWONGELA

MONITORING & EVALUATION OFFICER

A Monitoring and Evaluation professional, with 5 years’ experience in doing M&E for agriculture projects. He has previously worked for PP Sherpas Ltd (Farm Shine), Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), European Committee for Agriculture and Training (CEFA). Anselm is very passionate seeking innovative ways of performing complex tasks using digital means.

James Mwangangi

MONITORING & EVALUATION OFFICER

James is an experienced Monitoring and Evaluation Specialist with cutting edge expertise in Data and Analytics. He has over 4 years previous experience working with Caritas, Kitui as a Data Monitoring and Evaluation Specialist supporting a Carbon-Offset project (FASTENOPFER) and Agricultural sector (MISEREOR) – (Kitui and Makueni). Mwangangi holds a bachelor’s Degree in Economics and Statistics and currently enrolled to a Master of Science in Data Science and Analytics (MSc DSA) University of Nairobi.

John Makuge

KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT AND LEARNING OFFICER

Mr. Makuge is well experienced in project management, Monitoring Evaluation and learning, agribusiness management supply Chain management, Training Needs Assessment and Value Chain Analysis. He has a wealth of experience spanning over 6 years in implementation of donor funded projects accrued from working programmes and projects funded by (USAID, DFID, World Bank, WFP) aimed at working rural smallholder farmers towards increasing agricultural productivity thereby increasing their food and income security. He is passionate about Monitoring Evaluation and Learnings and working with agri-business value chain actors to derisk smallholder resource poor farmers in unearthing productivity and food security solutions as well improving youth engagement in agri-business

Lindah Mbaisi

PR & COMMUNICATIONS LEAD

Lindah is a Mandela Washington Fellow and a seasoned Public Relation (PR) and Communications specialist offering over 10 years’ cumulative experience in strategic communications from diverse sectors comprising not-for-profit organizations, membership organizations, communication, and the media industry. She is a highly result-oriented leader experienced in developing and implementing communications strategies, advocacy and developing compelling content for publicity. She holds a BA Communication Degree (PR Option) from Daystar University and has great experience leveraging consultative communication strategies that build mutually beneficial relationships across all target markets.

Julius Methuselah Nyabicha

PROJECT MANAGER

Julius holds a Master’s Degree in Agribusiness Management and has cross-border experience in food security and food safety. He has worked in the agriculture sector for Two decades, in both public and private sectors. Julius worked in Tanzania for 8 years supporting smallholder farmers in the fertilizer, horticulture, and post-harvest handling technologies (hermetic bags and Aflasafe bio-pesticide) for the control of aflatoxin in grains and pulses.

OSWALD MIRITI

PROJECT MANAGER

Agronomist with gained experience in Project Planning and Management with over 18 years of practice working with Agri-based private sector. With a background training in agronomy, Miriti has expertise in Farmer Mobilization for Collective Production and Marketing, Good Agricultural Practices, Value Chain Development, Project Development, Coordination and Partnership Management. Miriti has training from on Post Harvest Management from Louisiana State University Courtesy of United State Department of Agriculture (USDA), Fertilizers Advisor Certification and Training Scheme and Basic Certificate in Crop Protection by Basis Registration Limited UK and Integrated Pest Management (Level One) by Dudutech among others.

GEORGE MABUKA

PROJECT MANAGER

George has a background in community development with over 13 years of work experience working with farming communities in Kenya, 8 years of which, is in project management at different programs and capacities. Over the years, George is skilled in farmer mobilization, agricultural value chain development, project planning & management. He has also trained on; Participatory Rural Appraisal – Egerton University, Gender and Agriculture value chains – Kigali, Rwanda and Food security and Grain Storage technologies and Management – Tel Aviv University, Israel.

item.title: MAIN FOOTER
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
CGA's main purpose is to bring together commercial cereal farmers to promote collective action for the sustained improvement of their farming enterprises and in addressing industry challenges in Kenya.

item.title: Our Projects
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
FARM TO MARKET ALLIANCE (FTMA)

An initiative spearheaded by the UN World Food Programme (WFP) through a consortium of end-to-end value chain actors comprising of the following global members: the Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA), Grow Africa, RaboBank, the International Finance Corporation (IFC), Yara International, Syngenta and Bayer. 

MOBIGROW

This project is supported by KCB bank Limited

CEREAL VALUE CHAIN DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

This project is supported by French Development Agency (AFD) in partnership with Fert.  Fert is a French association for international cooperation for agricultural development in developing and emerging countries.

Vision

To be a leading Agribusiness solutions provider.

item.title: Market, Inoiut Linkage, Field Days

item.title: Home
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
[smartslider3 slider="4"]

SIGN UP TO OUR NEWSLETTER FOR NEWS AND UPDATES

SUBSCRIBE

WHO WE ARE

Cereals Growers Association (CGA) is a national non-profit member-based farmer organization incorporated in August 1996. Its main purpose is to bring together commercial cereal farmers to promote collective action for the sustained improvement of their farming enterprises and in addressing industry challenges in Kenya. Read More

WHAT WE DO

Farmer Presentation

CGA continuously engages the Government on behalf of its farmer members in a bid to ensure that we have favorable and sustainable agricultural policiesA line about the service you've mentioned above.

Farmer Linkage Services

We play the critical role of linking farmers with the following services.

Training, Research, and Advisory Services

CGA offers extension and advisory services to farmers through the establishment of learning centers and demo farms, farmer field days and trade fairs

Information Services

Through The Sower Magazine, a quarterly publication of CGA, we share crucial information to farmers such as Agri-tips, weather advisory and other farm economic observatory.

Mission

To provide farmers with agribusiness solutions through advocacy, technology, innovations and partnerships.

Vision

To be a leading Agribusiness solutions provider.

OUR REACH

+ Cereal and Pulses Value Chain Counties + Farmer Groups + Farmers + Household Members​

OUR PROJECTS

Over the past 12 years CGA has implemented a range of program activities resulting from patnerships in the donor community, government bodies and a number of players in the grain and agricultural sector in general.

FARM TO MARKET ALLIANCE (FTMA)

An initiative spearheaded by the UN World Food Programme (WFP) through a consortium of end-to-end value chain actors comprising of the following global members: the Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA), Grow Africa, RaboBank, the International Finance Corporation (IFC), Yara International, Syngenta and Bayer. 

MOBIGROW

This project is supported by KCB bank Limited

CEREAL VALUE CHAIN DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

This project is supported by French Development Agency (AFD) in partnership with Fert.  Fert is a French association for international cooperation for agricultural development in developing and emerging countries.

CEREALS VALUE ENHANCEMENT PROJECT

This project is supported by Christian Aid.

CROPMON

The project is supported by The Netherlands Space Office (NSO) and is implemented through – SoilCares Research as the lead partner

MORE PROJECTS

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
WHO IS CGA

Cereals Growers Association (CGA) is a national non-profit member-based farmer organization incorporated in August 1996. Its main purpose is to bring together commercial cereal farmers to promote collective action for the sustained improvement of their farming enterprises and in addressing industry challenges in Kenya.

CGA works with industry stakeholders such as government bodies, agricultural input suppliers, financial institutions, insurance companies, output buyers, development partners, Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) and others to provide services to its members.

CGA is headquartered in Nairobi and is on a day to day basis run by a team of thirteen (13) office-based professionals and field extension officers distributed across twenty-four (24) counties where we are operational. These are found in all the main cereal growing regions of Kenya and serving about 150,000 household members. The team is led by a Chief Executive Officer who is appointed by a Board of Trustees.

Mission

To provide farmers with agribusiness solutions through advocacy, technology, innovations and partnerships.

Vision

To be a leading Agribusiness solutions provider.

WHERE ARE WE

Cereal Growers Association is currently active in 25 counties all across Kenya.

Our physical location is at Mountain View Estate, Off Waiyaki Way.

WHY YOU SHOULD BECOME OUR MEMBER

Fastest Work

item.title: Services
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
WHAT WE DO

LETS MAKE FARMING PROFITABLE AND SUSTAINABLE
CEREAL FARMERS AND CGA: EMPOWERMENT

CGA offers cereal farmers a functional platform, structure and linkage to business-support services that grow their farming businesses and improves their livelihoods.

COLLECTIVE ACTION IN AGRICULTURE: STRENGTHENING FARMER'S BARGAINING POWER AND ECONOMIC VIABILITY

The foundation of CGA is within the logic that, cereal farmers working together as a unit have a higher bargaining power for favorable policy adjustments, better prices for their produce and they have the critical mass to enjoy economies of scale.

IMPROVING AGRICULTURE INFRASTRUCTURE FOR SMALL SCALE FARMERS

Farmers also enjoy better access to market information, adequate on-farm storage facilities, stable producer prices as well as adequate access to credit facilities and reliable market outlets

item.title: Contact
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
CONTACT US!

Connect with CGA

Facebook-f Twitter Instagram Linkedin Youtube

SUBSCRIBE NOW FOR CEREAL-GROWING TIPS AND SEIZE EXCITING JOB OPPORTUNITIES IN WITH CGA!

Unlock the secrets to growing and marketing cereal like never before with our exclusive newsletter! Gain insider knowledge, expert tips, and innovative strategies to cultivate bountiful crops and maximize profits. Stay ahead of the competition, with valuable insights on the latest trends, emerging technologies, and consumer preferences in the cereal industry. Join our community of passionate growers and savvy marketers who are transforming their businesses with our proven techniques. Don't miss out on this golden opportunity to elevate your cereal game and achieve unparalleled success. Subscribe now and embark on a journey to cereal-growing excellence!

Send us a Message!

Contact Details

Address

P.O BOX 27542, Mountain View
Off Waiyaki Way

Mail Us

info@cga.co.ke

Call Us

+254700222622

item.title: Who is CGA
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
WHO IS CGA

Cereals Growers Association (CGA) is a national non-profit member-based farmer organization incorporated in August 1996. Its main purpose is to bring together commercial cereal farmers to promote collective action for the sustained improvement of their farming enterprises and in addressing industry challenges in Kenya.

CGA works with industry stakeholders such as government bodies, agricultural input suppliers, financial institutions, insurance companies, output buyers, development partners, Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) and others to provide services to its members.

CGA is headquartered in Nairobi and is on a day to day basis run by a team of thirteen (13) office-based professionals and field extension officers distributed across twenty-four (24) counties where we are operational. These are found in all the main cereal growing regions of Kenya and serving about 150,000 household members. The team is led by a Chief Executive Officer who is appointed by a Board of Trustees.

Mission

To provide farmers with agribusiness solutions through advocacy, technology, innovations and partnerships.

Vision

To be a leading Agribusiness solutions provider.

WHY YOU SHOULD BECOME OUR MEMBER

Fastest Work

Fill

High Skill

Fill.

Clean Work

Fill

Proper Take Care

Fill

Join us now

  • Play the video
+ Cereal and Pulse Value Chains 0 Counties in Kenya + Farmer Groups + Farmers + Household Members

item.title: CGA Leadership
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
Anthony Kioko

Chief Executive Officer

Anthony Kioko is an East Africa Agribusiness expert with 20 years’ experience managing public – private sector engagement initiatives. An agronomist by training, his previous management positions were at Oil Crop Development Ltd (Unilever Kenya Ltd subsidiary then), East African Breweries Ltd (a Diageo Plc Company). He was a beneficiary of the 2017 USDA FAS Cochran Fellowship Program, on Agricultural Extension and Farmer Leadership. Anthony serves on several boards including the Seed Trade Association of Kenya (STAK), Agriculture Industry Network (AIN) and is a Council Member of the Agriculture Sector Network (ASNET). Anthony is also a member of several Technical Working Groups in the Agriculture Sector including the Joint Thematic Working Group of the Ministry of Agriculture Livestock Fisheries and Cooperatives (MOALF&C) and ASNET.

Fredrick Muma

FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION MANAGER

Fredrick oversees the finance and administration functions of accounting, financial management, human resources, administration and their strategic contribution to CGA’s work. He is a financial expert with over seven years of experience in auditing, financial management, grants management, project management and administration gained from the private non-governmental sectors. Fredrick is currently pursuing M. Sc. Finance (Finance and Investment) from the University of Nairobi; he holds a Bachelor of Economics and Finance degree from Kenyatta University and is a Certified Public Accountant (CPA-K) and an active member of the Institute of Certified Public Accountants of Kenya (ICPAK). Fredrick is also a Certified Financial Modeling and Valuation Analyst (FMVA) by the Corporate Finance Institute (CFI). Fredrick joined CGA in January 2014 prior to which he worked as an audit associate at the Crowe Horwarth EA Audit firm.

ALVIN OGOLLA

FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT

A result oriented individual, passionate about creating positive impact that matters in the society. With over 3yrs working experience, he assists in the administrative and financial roles in CGA. Alvin holds a Bachelor of Economics and Finance degree from Kenyatta University with training on Financial modelling and data analysis. He has previously worked with Kenya Association of Hotelkeepers & Caterers (KAHC), Tribe Hotel and Brocahoto Sacco Ltd.

Wight Ndambuki

project Accountant

Wight has working experience in financial and administrative support with bias in accounting functions. With over 3 years’ experience in finance and accounting on programme-based grants such as UN – World Food Programme, USAID, AGRA, FERT, RTI International, Australian High Commission -Kenya, AATF, Netherlands Space Office, Christian Aid, IFPRI and the Business Advocacy Fund. Wight has passion for numbers and skilled in financial accountability and reporting. Wight is at an advanced stage towards full professional training in Certified Public Accounting. Previously Wight has received training in Ethics and Communication at Strathmore University.

Violet Nyando

MEMBERSHIP, POLICY AND ADVOCACY MANAGER

Agricultural Innovation Expert with background training in Agricultural Rural Innovations Studies. With over 15 years of experience, Violet has expertise in the areas of Agricultural Innovations including Climate Smart Agriculture, Agricultural Policy Development, Institutional Development and Strengthening, Agricultural Advisory and Extension, Agricultural Product Value Chain Development, Gender Analysis and Mainstreaming, Governance and Leadership of Agri-Enterprises and Public Policy Lobby and Advocacy Processes. Violet is also skilled and facilitating public-private sector dialogue forums.

SAMUEL OSEBE

FIELD LOGISTICS SUPPORT MANAGER

Samuel Osebe is an experienced strategic project management and implementation expert with over 10 years’ progressive experience gained from working in various capacities. He has successfully supported multiple CGA projects, partners and stakeholders in their business linkage activities including trade fairs. Highly proficient in supply chain / logistics management.

ANSELM MWONGELA

MONITORING & EVALUATION OFFICER

A Monitoring and Evaluation professional, with 5 years’ experience in doing M&E for agriculture projects. He has previously worked for PP Sherpas Ltd (Farm Shine), Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), European Committee for Agriculture and Training (CEFA). Anselm is very passionate seeking innovative ways of performing complex tasks using digital means.

James Mwangangi

MONITORING & EVALUATION OFFICER

James is an experienced Monitoring and Evaluation Specialist with cutting edge expertise in Data and Analytics. He has over 4 years previous experience working with Caritas, Kitui as a Data Monitoring and Evaluation Specialist supporting a Carbon-Offset project (FASTENOPFER) and Agricultural sector (MISEREOR) – (Kitui and Makueni). Mwangangi holds a bachelor’s Degree in Economics and Statistics and currently enrolled to a Master of Science in Data Science and Analytics (MSc DSA) University of Nairobi.

John Makuge

KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT AND LEARNING OFFICER

Mr. Makuge is well experienced in project management, Monitoring Evaluation and learning, agribusiness management supply Chain management, Training Needs Assessment and Value Chain Analysis. He has a wealth of experience spanning over 6 years in implementation of donor funded projects accrued from working programmes and projects funded by (USAID, DFID, World Bank, WFP) aimed at working rural smallholder farmers towards increasing agricultural productivity thereby increasing their food and income security. He is passionate about Monitoring Evaluation and Learnings and working with agri-business value chain actors to derisk smallholder resource poor farmers in unearthing productivity and food security solutions as well improving youth engagement in agri-business

Lindah Mbaisi

PR & COMMUNICATIONS LEAD

Lindah is a Mandela Washington Fellow and a seasoned Public Relation (PR) and Communications specialist offering over 10 years’ cumulative experience in strategic communications from diverse sectors comprising not-for-profit organizations, membership organizations, communication, and the media industry. She is a highly result-oriented leader experienced in developing and implementing communications strategies, advocacy and developing compelling content for publicity. She holds a BA Communication Degree (PR Option) from Daystar University and has great experience leveraging consultative communication strategies that build mutually beneficial relationships across all target markets.

Julius Methuselah Nyabicha

PROJECT MANAGER

Julius holds a Master’s Degree in Agribusiness Management and has cross-border experience in food security and food safety. He has worked in the agriculture sector for Two decades, in both public and private sectors. Julius worked in Tanzania for 8 years supporting smallholder farmers in the fertilizer, horticulture, and post-harvest handling technologies (hermetic bags and Aflasafe bio-pesticide) for the control of aflatoxin in grains and pulses.

OSWALD MIRITI

PROJECT MANAGER

Agronomist with gained experience in Project Planning and Management with over 18 years of practice working with Agri-based private sector. With a background training in agronomy, Miriti has expertise in Farmer Mobilization for Collective Production and Marketing, Good Agricultural Practices, Value Chain Development, Project Development, Coordination and Partnership Management. Miriti has training from on Post Harvest Management from Louisiana State University Courtesy of United State Department of Agriculture (USDA), Fertilizers Advisor Certification and Training Scheme and Basic Certificate in Crop Protection by Basis Registration Limited UK and Integrated Pest Management (Level One) by Dudutech among others.

GEORGE MABUKA

PROJECT MANAGER

George has a background in community development with over 13 years of work experience working with farming communities in Kenya, 8 years of which, is in project management at different programs and capacities. Over the years, George is skilled in farmer mobilization, agricultural value chain development, project planning & management. He has also trained on; Participatory Rural Appraisal – Egerton University, Gender and Agriculture value chains – Kigali, Rwanda and Food security and Grain Storage technologies and Management – Tel Aviv University, Israel.

item.title: Board of Directors
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
FARNIE KRUGER

Chairman and a large scale wheat and maize farmer in North Rift, Eldoret

MARTIN DYER

Vice Chairman and a large scale wheat farmer in Mt.Kenya Region,Timau

MICHAEL M. NYACHAE

Chairman of the Cereal Growers SACCO and a large scale wheat and maize farmer in Narok.

PROF. MIRIAM KINYUA

Chairman and a large scale wheat and maize farmer in North Rift, Eldoret

NAHSON NGETICH

Board member, farmer and Communication System Engineer at Cooperative Bank

STEVE ROSE

Board member and a wheat and maize large scale farmer in Nakuru

item.title: HQ Staff
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
Anthony Kioko

Chief Executive Officer

Anthony Kioko is an East Africa Agribusiness expert with 20 years’ experience managing public – private sector engagement initiatives. An agronomist by training, his previous management positions were at Oil Crop Development Ltd (Unilever Kenya Ltd subsidiary then), East African Breweries Ltd (a Diageo Plc Company). He was a beneficiary of the 2017 USDA FAS Cochran Fellowship Program, on Agricultural Extension and Farmer Leadership. Anthony serves on several boards including the Seed Trade Association of Kenya (STAK), Agriculture Industry Network (AIN) and is a Council Member of the Agriculture Sector Network (ASNET). Anthony is also a member of several Technical Working Groups in the Agriculture Sector including the Joint Thematic Working Group of the Ministry of Agriculture Livestock Fisheries and Cooperatives (MOALF&C) and ASNET.

Fredrick Muma

FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION MANAGER

Fredrick oversees the finance and administration functions of accounting, financial management, human resources, administration and their strategic contribution to CGA’s work. He is a financial expert with over seven years of experience in auditing, financial management, grants management, project management and administration gained from the private non-governmental sectors. Fredrick is currently pursuing M. Sc. Finance (Finance and Investment) from the University of Nairobi; he holds a Bachelor of Economics and Finance degree from Kenyatta University and is a Certified Public Accountant (CPA-K) and an active member of the Institute of Certified Public Accountants of Kenya (ICPAK). Fredrick is also a Certified Financial Modeling and Valuation Analyst (FMVA) by the Corporate Finance Institute (CFI). Fredrick joined CGA in January 2014 prior to which he worked as an audit associate at the Crowe Horwarth EA Audit firm.

ALVIN OGOLLA

FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT

A result oriented individual, passionate about creating positive impact that matters in the society. With over 3yrs working experience, he assists in the administrative and financial roles in CGA. Alvin holds a Bachelor of Economics and Finance degree from Kenyatta University with training on Financial modelling and data analysis. He has previously worked with Kenya Association of Hotelkeepers & Caterers (KAHC), Tribe Hotel and Brocahoto Sacco Ltd.

Wight Ndambuki

project Accountant

Wight has working experience in financial and administrative support with bias in accounting functions. With over 3 years’ experience in finance and accounting on programme-based grants such as UN – World Food Programme, USAID, AGRA, FERT, RTI International, Australian High Commission -Kenya, AATF, Netherlands Space Office, Christian Aid, IFPRI and the Business Advocacy Fund. Wight has passion for numbers and skilled in financial accountability and reporting. Wight is at an advanced stage towards full professional training in Certified Public Accounting. Previously Wight has received training in Ethics and Communication at Strathmore University.

Violet Nyando

MEMBERSHIP, POLICY AND ADVOCACY MANAGER

Agricultural Innovation Expert with background training in Agricultural Rural Innovations Studies. With over 15 years of experience, Violet has expertise in the areas of Agricultural Innovations including Climate Smart Agriculture, Agricultural Policy Development, Institutional Development and Strengthening, Agricultural Advisory and Extension, Agricultural Product Value Chain Development, Gender Analysis and Mainstreaming, Governance and Leadership of Agri-Enterprises and Public Policy Lobby and Advocacy Processes. Violet is also skilled and facilitating public-private sector dialogue forums.

SAMUEL OSEBE

FIELD LOGISTICS SUPPORT MANAGER

Samuel Osebe is an experienced strategic project management and implementation expert with over 10 years’ progressive experience gained from working in various capacities. He has successfully supported multiple CGA projects, partners and stakeholders in their business linkage activities including trade fairs. Highly proficient in supply chain / logistics management.

ANSELM MWONGELA

MONITORING & EVALUATION OFFICER

A Monitoring and Evaluation professional, with 5 years’ experience in doing M&E for agriculture projects. He has previously worked for PP Sherpas Ltd (Farm Shine), Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), European Committee for Agriculture and Training (CEFA). Anselm is very passionate seeking innovative ways of performing complex tasks using digital means.

James Mwangangi

MONITORING & EVALUATION OFFICER

James is an experienced Monitoring and Evaluation Specialist with cutting edge expertise in Data and Analytics. He has over 4 years previous experience working with Caritas, Kitui as a Data Monitoring and Evaluation Specialist supporting a Carbon-Offset project (FASTENOPFER) and Agricultural sector (MISEREOR) – (Kitui and Makueni). Mwangangi holds a bachelor’s Degree in Economics and Statistics and currently enrolled to a Master of Science in Data Science and Analytics (MSc DSA) University of Nairobi.

John Makuge

KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT AND LEARNING OFFICER

Mr. Makuge is well experienced in project management, Monitoring Evaluation and learning, agribusiness management supply Chain management, Training Needs Assessment and Value Chain Analysis. He has a wealth of experience spanning over 6 years in implementation of donor funded projects accrued from working programmes and projects funded by (USAID, DFID, World Bank, WFP) aimed at working rural smallholder farmers towards increasing agricultural productivity thereby increasing their food and income security. He is passionate about Monitoring Evaluation and Learnings and working with agri-business value chain actors to derisk smallholder resource poor farmers in unearthing productivity and food security solutions as well improving youth engagement in agri-business

Lindah Mbaisi

PR & COMMUNICATIONS LEAD

Lindah is a Mandela Washington Fellow and a seasoned Public Relation (PR) and Communications specialist offering over 10 years’ cumulative experience in strategic communications from diverse sectors comprising not-for-profit organizations, membership organizations, communication, and the media industry. She is a highly result-oriented leader experienced in developing and implementing communications strategies, advocacy and developing compelling content for publicity. She holds a BA Communication Degree (PR Option) from Daystar University and has great experience leveraging consultative communication strategies that build mutually beneficial relationships across all target markets.

Julius Methuselah Nyabicha

PROJECT MANAGER

Julius holds a Master’s Degree in Agribusiness Management and has cross-border experience in food security and food safety. He has worked in the agriculture sector for Two decades, in both public and private sectors. Julius worked in Tanzania for 8 years supporting smallholder farmers in the fertilizer, horticulture, and post-harvest handling technologies (hermetic bags and Aflasafe bio-pesticide) for the control of aflatoxin in grains and pulses.

OSWALD MIRITI

PROJECT MANAGER

Agronomist with gained experience in Project Planning and Management with over 18 years of practice working with Agri-based private sector. With a background training in agronomy, Miriti has expertise in Farmer Mobilization for Collective Production and Marketing, Good Agricultural Practices, Value Chain Development, Project Development, Coordination and Partnership Management. Miriti has training from on Post Harvest Management from Louisiana State University Courtesy of United State Department of Agriculture (USDA), Fertilizers Advisor Certification and Training Scheme and Basic Certificate in Crop Protection by Basis Registration Limited UK and Integrated Pest Management (Level One) by Dudutech among others.

GEORGE MABUKA

PROJECT MANAGER

George has a background in community development with over 13 years of work experience working with farming communities in Kenya, 8 years of which, is in project management at different programs and capacities. Over the years, George is skilled in farmer mobilization, agricultural value chain development, project planning & management. He has also trained on; Participatory Rural Appraisal – Egerton University, Gender and Agriculture value chains – Kigali, Rwanda and Food security and Grain Storage technologies and Management – Tel Aviv University, Israel.

item.title: Service Directory
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
FARMER REPRESENTATION

CGA continuously engages the Government on behalf of its farmer members in a bid to ensure that we have favorable and sustainable agricultural policies. CGA picks up concerns raised by its farmer members in the cereal sub-sector and addresses them with the Government through evidence based lobbying and advocacy.

TRAINING, RESEARCH AND ADVISORY SERVICES

CGA offers extension and advisory services to farmers through the establishment of learning centers and demo farms, farmer field days and trade fairs. CGA also offers affordable soil testing services.

FARMER LINKAGE SERVICES

We play the critical role of linking farmers with the following services.

  • Financial Service Linkage

    Cereal Growers SACCO Society Ltd, CGA offers farmers an opportunity to save and get affordable and viable credit for their agricultural activities.

  • Market linkage

    When farmers come together, they have a higher bargaining power. Therefore, CGA helps to bring farmers together in the aggregation of crop produce for easier joint marketing. While working together with specific development partners, CGA trains and facilitates farmers to aggregate and jointly market their produce.

  • Input procurement

    We facilitate our farmer members to procure farm inputs in bulk thereby attracting quantity discounts while reducing incidences of buying fake inputs.

INFORMATION SERVICES

Through The Sower Magazine, a quarterly publication of CGA, we share crucial information to farmers such as Agri-tips, weather advisory and other farm economic observatory. Other information sharing platforms include The Cereal Notebook, a monthly e-publication that shares key highlights within the cereal sub-sector. We also have a bulk SMS platform that helps disburse information to over 150,000 cereal farmers in our database.

item.title: Projects
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
• All
  • FTMA
  • SCI
  • KENYA SCP
  • CVCD
  • CVEP
  • RA
FARM TO MARKET ALLIANCE (FTMA)

The Farm to Market Alliance (FtMA) is an initiative spearheaded by the WFP

SORGHUM COMMERCIALIZATION INITIATIVE (SCI)

This project is supported USAID - Fintrac (Partnering For Innovation).

KENYA SORGHUM COMMERCIALIZATION PROJECT (KENYA SCP)

The project is supported by AgriFi Challenge Fund (Self Help Africa).

CEREAL VALUE CHAIN DEVELOPMENT (CVCD)

This project is supported by French Development Agency (AFD) in partnership with FERT.

CEREALS VALUE ENHANCEMENT PROJECT (CVEP)

This project is supported by Christian Aid.

REGENERATIVE AGRICULTURE

Funded by IKEA foundation through Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA)
Farm Africa, International Institute for Rural Reconstruction (IIRR) and County Government of Makueni Agriculture department

item.title: GET INVOLVED
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
JOIN US AT

CGA

"Join Our Team and Make a Difference!"

View Openings

WHY WORK AT CGA

At CGA, you have the opportunity to make a meaningful impact on the cereal farming industry in Kenya. As a national non-profit organization, we bring together commercial farmers, collaborate with key stakeholders, and address industry challenges. Join our dedicated team of professionals and field extension officers who are actively working across multiple counties to support our members and their farming enterprises. By working at CGA, you can contribute to the sustained improvement of agriculture, foster collective action, and be part of shaping a brighter future for cereal growers in Kenya. Together, let's make a difference in the lives of thousands of farming households.

LATEST JOB POSTING

THERE ARE CURRENTLY NO JOB POSTINGS FROM CGA WITHIN THE LAST MONTH

PREVIOUS JOB POSTINGS

Join our dedicated team of professionals and field extension officers who are actively working across multiple counties to support our members and their farming enterprises. By working at CGA, you can contribute to the sustained improvement of agriculture, foster collective action, and be part of shaping a brighter future for cereal growers in Kenya. Together, let's make a difference in the lives of thousands of farming households.<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Poppins","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":16,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"em","size":2,"sizes":[]},"_padding":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"15","left":"0","isLinked":false},"eael_tooltip_section_content":"I am a tooltip","eael_ext_content_protection_password_placeholder":"Enter Password","eael_ext_content_protection_password_submit_btn_txt":"Submit","typography_font_size_tablet":{"unit":"px","size":14,"sizes":[]},"eael_ext_content_protection_password_incorrect_message":"Password does not match.","eael_cl_logics":[{"_id":"c5d493b"}]},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"1b49d8f","elType":"section","settings":{"background_background":"classic","background_color":"#1A4525","animation":"fadeInUp"},"elements":[{"id":"26408cc","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"ec03d3e","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"LATEST JOB POSTING","align":"center"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"5f4ef74","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

item.title: Individual Farmers Category
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
WHY BECOME A CGA MEMBER

As a CGA farmer member, you enjoy the following benefits:

  • Farmer representation in policy advocacy and joint lobbying actions on key issues affecting Cereal Farmers – CGA continuously engages the Government in evidence-based advocacy to ensure formulation and implementation of agricultural policies that favor cereal farmers.
  • Priority in beneficiary selection – CGA works with development partners to implement projects within the cereal sub-sector. We give priority to our registered farmer members at group level who enjoy varying project benefits.
  • Access to farmer training fora – we facilitate the training of our farmer member groups to build their capacities to engage other players in their respective value chains.
  • Linkage to Output Marketing – we train and facilitate farmers to undertake aggregation and jointly market their produce.
  • Linkage to Credit Service Providers – we train and facilitate farmers to access affordable credit through the Cereal Growers SACCO Society Ltd.
  • Input Procurement Services – we facilitate members to procure farm inputs in bulk thereby attracting quantity discounts and reducing chances of buying fake inputs.
    Easy and free access and exposure to information and new technologies related to Agriculture through:
  • The Sower – A quarterly publication of CGA distributed Free of costs to our farmer members at the county level through our field officers.
  • Cereal Notebook – A monthly E-publication that provides key highlights within the cereal subsector.
  • Field Days – Interactive & information sharing events that bring together relevant player within the agricultural sector..

BECOME A MEMBER

REGISTER

item.title: Associate Membership
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
BENEFITS OF AN ASSOCIATE MEMBER

As an associate member, you get the following benefits:

Linkage to our farmer members – CGA has a database of over 150,000 farmers who we mobilize and profile to facilitate group action in input procurement marketing of their produce, credit access, and in implementing our development partner funded projects.

Discounted advertising in CGA information sharing platforms – The Sower Magazine, The Cereal Notebook, Bulk SMS platform.

Discounted exhibition rates at different CGA events where you are guaranteed of a large bona fide farmer turnout

Opportunity to work with CGA farmer groups for comparative input testing in their demo sites which results in an endorsement of the best agricultural inputs amongst our farmer members.

REGISTER AS AN ASSOCIATE MEMBER

REGISTER

item.title: Partners
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
WHY PARTNERSHIPS?

THIS IS FILLER TEXT, DO NOT USE IT.

Partnerships is how we deliver on our mandate of accessing, adapting and delivering technologies to smallholder farmers for improved productivity. We recognise that we cannot, on our own, accomplish the goal of technology transfer and we therefore seek the synergy and complementarity of other players along the agricultural food value chain.

Our partnerships bring together national, continental and international entities including farmers and farmer organisations; national and international research organisations; central and local governments; public and private extension service providers; NGOs and community based organisations; regional and sub-regional organisations; business enterprises; youth and women groups; and public and private investors.

We believe that meaningful, effective and efficient partnerships must be nurtured for them to deliver intended results and we are therefore committed to building enduring relationships that will steer technologies through challenges to attain the end goal.

Some Projects Our Partners Help Us With

  • Uncategorized

    Cereal Value Chain Development (CVCD) Project

    This project is supported by French Development Agency (AFD) in partnership with Fert.  Fert is a French association for international cooperation for agricultural development in developing and emerging countries. Geographical Coverage NakuruNarokUasin Gishu as

    Published by Joshua
  • Uncategorized

    KENYA SORGHUM COMMERCIALIZATION PROJECT (KENYA SCP)

    Geographic Coverage Currently, the project is being implemented in the following counties:MakueniKituiBusiaTharaka NithiKisumuHomabayMeruSiayaBusiaTarget Value Chain:Sorghum

    Published by Joshua
  • Uncategorized

    Sorghum Commercialization Initiative (SCI)

    Geographic Coverage Currently, the project is being implemented in the following counties:MakuenKituiMeru Tharaka NithiHomabayKisumuSiayaBusiaTarget Value Chain:Sorghum

    Published by Joshua
  • FtMA

    Farm to Market Alliance (FtMA)

    The Farm to Market Alliance (FtMA) is an initiative spearheaded by the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) through a consortium of end-to-end value chain actors comprising of the following

    Published by Joshua
    • Cereal Value Chain Development (CVCD) Project
    • KENYA SORGHUM COMMERCIALIZATION PROJECT (KENYA SCP)
    • Sorghum Commercialization Initiative (SCI)
    • Farm to Market Alliance (FtMA)

    OUR PARTNERS

WHY PARTNERSHIPS?<\/p>","align":"center","text_color":"#E89D43","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Aleo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"vw","size":4.5,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_size_tablet":{"unit":"vw","size":"","sizes":[]},"typography_font_size_mobile":{"unit":"vw","size":"","sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"2069667","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Partnerships is how we deliver on our mandate of accessing, adapting and delivering technologies to smallholder farmers for improved productivity. We recognise that we cannot, on our own, accomplish the goal of technology transfer and we therefore seek the synergy and complementarity of other players along the agricultural food value chain.<\/p>

Our partnerships bring together national, continental and international entities including farmers and farmer organisations; national and international research organisations; central and local governments; public and private extension service providers; NGOs and community based organisations; regional and sub-regional organisations; business enterprises; youth and women groups; and public and private investors.<\/p>

We believe that meaningful, effective and efficient partnerships must be nurtured for them to deliver intended results and we are therefore committed to building enduring relationships that will steer technologies through challenges to attain the end item.title: Regenerative Agriculture and Climate Smart Agriculture technologies increase income and crop production in Makueni County.
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
“Today I don’t regret to have come back to the village as I have good income.”

For many years, smallholder farmers in Makueni County have faced several challenges including adverse effects of climate change, land degradation, declining soil fertility, limited access to extension services and weak input and output market linkages. Low agricultural productivity has resulted to limited participation in agricultural markets leading to increased food insecurity, poor household nutrition and weak economic resilience among smallholder farmers.

To break the cycle, AGRA and implementing partner CGA have focused on Scaling Out Regenerative Agricultural Practices in eastern Kenya. The project aims to improve food security, community and ecosystems resilience through adoption of regenerative agriculture and climate smart practices and technologies among smallholder farmers and to strengthen the community-based public-private extension system in the county.  

Justus Kimeu is a 46-year-old farmer and father of four children and the chairperson of the Makueni Conservation farmers CBO in Kathiani Village, Makueni County. He earns most of his money from farming. Kimeu quit his job as a social worker in 2007, returned to the village and went direct into farming.

But despite the success of his first try in farming, Kimeu knew that he had a lot to learn about farming. “Like in any profession, agriculture needs training and updating knowledge and practices. I lacked deep knowledge of farming and instead used conventional farming practices,” he confessed.

In 2020, Kimeu received Regenerative Agriculture training and support from CGA by a Village Based Advisor (VBA) through a mother demo plot established at Kithoni. He attended weekly training to learn better farm practices, such as land preparation, timely planting, proper spacing, row cropping, crop rotation, mulching, intercropping of cereal and pulses that fix nitrogen from the atmosphere, and conservation agriculture. After weeks of training, Kimeu received improved seeds with the help of the VBA from input suppliers and later established a baby demo farm.

“I now use principles of regenerative agriculture, such as crop rotation, crop residue retention, crop cover crops and minimum tillage to help the soil give its maximum output,” says Kimeu.

Using the Village Based Advisors (VBAs) business model, the project demonstrates improved RA practices and technologies, using Mother-Baby approach. This approach facilitates farmer learning from the demonstration site – ‘mother’ and trialing on their own plots – ‘baby’. Comparison is then made on performance of ‘mother and baby’ plots to assess level of learning and adoption of trained practices and technologies by farmers.

“Before the project began in Makueni, my yields were very low due to traditional farming techniques and poor farming practices. I would only harvest 3 -10 bags of maize in the 3 acres. Now I harvest an average of 40 to 60 bags in 6 acres,” says Kimeu.

“Since I started using these regenerative agriculture practices and technologies, my production costs have decreased between 20-30 % while my crop yields have increased from 1 bag – 3.3 bags per acre to 6.7 bags – 10 bags per acre depending on the season. Today I don’t regret to have come back to the village as I have good income,” added Kimeu.

As a result, he is now considered a resource person on the use of Regenerative Agriculture and Climate Smart Agriculture practices in his village. With the earnings from his farming, Kimeu is paying for his children’s education and has heavily invested in water harvesting tanks at his homestead. His rain harvesting systems efficiently captures enough water to leave him with over 200,000 liters at any point in time, enough to not only run his homestead but practice crop irrigation as needed.

Kimeu is a firm believer in the principles of total sustainability, and this is evident from his superbly developed farm, which is designed to ensure it is self-sustaining in every way. Kimeu has deployed the practices of RA, including intercropping, mulching, cover crop and soil and water conservation practices such as terraces.

He plants different crops (green grams, maize, beans) every season to increase moisture and fix nitrogen in the soil. He has also planted over 1,000 trees around the farm, effectively acting as windbreakers and protecting crops such as maize from strong winds.

“I plant green grams, or maize and beans in between the citrus trees. For weeding, I use a shallow weeder,” says Kimeu, who has been farming for over a decade now. He does not use the burn, or slash methods of clearing the farm because these are methods that leave the land bare, exposing the soil. If it is beans or greengrams he plucks the pods and leaves the stock,” he said.

Kimeu has introduced underneath water basins to collect and retain water during dry seasons and is using organic fertilizers. He also incorporates cover crops such as beans, green peas and pigeon peas, pumpkins, sweet potatoes, and watermelons. These crops help in weed management, prevents direct sunlight exposure to the soil. They also help in maintaining soil moisture and fixing nitrogen into the soil.

Today, many smallholder farmers from Kathiani village are inspired by his success and are now able to increase their income without damaging the environment by using regenerative agriculture and climate smart agriculture practices and technologies.

With AGRA’s support, CGA’s Regenerative Agriculture project trains smallholder farmers in Makueni to boost their production, minimize post-harvest losses, and improve their marketing skills through business to business (B2B) linkages. Across Makueni County, CGA is currently training over 10,000 farmers on RA through Village Based Advisors to improve their production and connect to markets.

The Regenerative Agriculture project is supported by Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA) through the IKEA Foundation and implemented by Cereal Growers Association (CGA).

item.title: Technical and Economic: Interdependent Pillars for an Efficient Advice to Farmers
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
Farmers employ different strategies when it comes to farming. For instance, for land preparation, options available could be conventional ploughing plus harrowing, minimum tillage through ripping/chiselling and application of herbicides (glyphosate) etc. Above the technical skills involved, there are cost implications and economic impact associated with these strategies.

 

Therefore, CGA aspires to equip farmers with the necessary skills to analysis their farming enterprise, make informed decision based on facts/figures and experiences sharing.

As key indicators and tools for decision-making, CGA has retained:

  • Gross Margin[1] and cost of production split to evaluate the performance of farm enterprises as well as alternative technical strategies or crops.
  • Cashflow[2] For a family farm, cash availability is critical to not only being able to finance daily expenses on the farm and for the household, but also invest or make savings. It requires a constant balancing between household expenses and operational needs of the farm. It calls for forecasting cash inflows and outflows of money to make the best decisions on the farming strategies (early input procurement, storage of produces, organising the crop and husbandry cycles for best complementarity of inflows and outflows calendar)

Getting these indicators/tools implies that farmers keep records of their costs and incomes. A record booklet has thus been developed. The data collected are then uploaded on a digital platform that enables data analysis.

Those economic data are valuated during a season assessment, a process where farmers come together after the season to review and compare their different farm operations strategies, discuss the associated costs and performances and collectively seek solutions to improve their farm profitability.

The process includes the following steps:

  1. Global overview and information about the season: rain patterns, incidences of pests and diseases, yields, market, prices…
  2. Sharing discussion about farm operations strategies (technical information): land preparation method, date of planting, type of fertilizers used…
  3. Economic data presentation, discussion and comparison. Here, 3 or more volunteer farmers who had recorded their farm operation costs share their figures about their cost of production, their income and the gross margin generated.
  4. Cashflow management discussion, based on the example of the farmers who had recorded their monthly cash flows.5. Ways forward and decision-making: combining the technical and economic discussions, farmers, with the support of CGA field staff, draw the lessons and decide what practices and procurement or market strategies they would like to keep, change, seek more information about… for improved farm management. decisions can be at individual farm level, as well as at the group level (joint early procurement of inputs …). These discussions are transcribed into an action-plan, highlighting the training and support needs from CGA. 6. Accompaniment of the group in the implementation if the decision taken alla long the following season.

On 1st December 2022, CGA piloted a season assessment meeting with Nalepo Women Group in Oloropil ward in Narok County, the group came together to start merry go round out of the money they used to get from the casual labour work.

The season has experienced depressed rains, pest and diseases outbursts which required more sprayings and farmers faced difficulty to access good quality inputs.

Also, despite good maize prices, the weight of the bag while selling to local traders was questioned with some farmers claiming the bags could weight up-to 150kgs (no clear standard of measurement to ascertain the weights). Interestingly, Sylvia a local trader who was present in the meeting, tried to explain her reason for buying at such weight, claiming that the farmers were harvesting at higher moisture contents that required additional drying. It was such a heated debate. CGA will dig deep into this conversation to support the farmers to find amicable solution.

On yield the farmers said that with the season had not been good, yields ranging from 10 to 15 bags/acre while in a good season they normally harvest around 22 90kgs bags/acre.

But even a difference of 5 bags on an acre becomes significant in a context of low production. The group then went to the comparison of their farm operation strategies to find some explanations of the difference among farmers.

The discussions revealed the importance of early planting in the context of lack of rains and the care to put in acquiring good quality inputs.

Then, the discussions around the economic results of 3 farmers who have kept records enable to put in perspectives the financial impact of technical choices like ploughing vs ripping, using manure vs inorganic fertilizer.

Out of the discussion, the farmers were able to agree on the following as a way forward;

  1. Continue/start keeping records – CGA will provide training and support
  2. Training needs: good agricultural practices (through a demo), agrochemical use, post-harvest handling
  3. To mitigate the challenge of counterfeit inputs, aggregate the needs for seeds and fertilizers – CGA will link with suppliers to get genuine inputs.
  4. Set weighing standards to avoid issues of farmers selling at undetermined weights and consider selling as a group to avoid exploitation by the local traders.

“During the season assessment] it was very instructive to discuss with my members about our practices this season and we could see the economic impact of planting late or using minimum tillage and the number of fertilizer applications for example. We have agreed on some way forwards like aggregating demand for seeds and trying to do minimum tillage.” Says Mary, Chairlady of NALEPO Women Group, Narok County.

Through this exercise, CGA was able to confirm the relevance of collecting farm technico-economic results and discussing them collectively as a group during season assessment in supporting farmers in the improvement of their farming system and thus their income.

NOTES: [1] Gross margin (GM) is the difference between the gross income and farm operation costs. It doesn’t consider the fixed costs (depreciation, taxes, credit costs, etc.), which can be difficult to calculate and/or neglectable for small scale farmers. [2] Cashflow is the total amount of cash available on the farm or at the household level. It is based on the difference between cash inflows and cash outflows.

    3. Economic data presentation, discussion and comparison. Here, 3 or more volunteer farmers who had recorded their farm operation costs share their figures about their cost of production, their income and the gross margin generated.<\/li>
    4. Cashflow management discussion, based on the example of the farmers who had recorded their monthly cash flows.5. Ways forward and decision-making: combining the technical and economic discussions, farmers, with the support of CGA field staff, draw the lessons and decide what practices and procurement or market strategies they would like to keep, change, seek more information about\u2026 for improved farm management. decisions can be at individual farm level, as well as at the group level (joint early procurement of inputs \u2026). These discussions are transcribed into an action-plan, highlighting the training and support needs from CGA. 6. Accompaniment of the group in the implementation if the decision taken alla long the following season.<\/li><\/ol>

      On 1st<\/sup>\u00a0December 2022, CGA piloted a season assessment meeting with Nalepo Women Group in Oloropil ward in Narok County, the group came together to start merry go round out of the money they used to get from the casual labour work.<\/p>

      The season has experienced depressed rains, pest and diseases outbursts which required more sprayings and farmers faced difficulty to access good quality inputs.<\/p>

      Also, despite good maize prices, the weight of the bag while selling to local traders was questioned with some farmers claiming the bags could weight up-to 150kgs (no clear standard of measurement to ascertain the weights). Interestingly, Sylvia a local trader who was present in the meeting, tried to explain her reason for buying at such weight, claiming that the farmers were harvesting at higher moisture contents that required additional drying. It was such a heated debate. CGA will dig deep into this conversation to support the farmers to find amicable solution.<\/p>

      On yield the farmers said that with the season had not been good, yields ranging from 10 to 15 bags\/acre while in a good season they normally harvest around 22 90kgs bags\/acre.<\/p>

      But even a difference of 5 bags on an acre becomes significant in a context of low production. The group then went to the comparison of their farm operation strategies to find some explanations of the difference among farmers.<\/p>

      The discussions revealed the importance of early planting in the context of lack of rains and the care to put in acquiring good quality inputs.<\/p>

      Then, the discussions around the economic results of 3 farmers who have kept records enable to put in perspectives the financial impact of technical choices like ploughing vs ripping, using manure vs inorganic fertilizer.<\/p>

      Out of the discussion, the farmers were able to agree on the following as a way forward;<\/p>

      1. Continue\/start keeping records \u2013 CGA will provide training and support<\/li>
      2. Training needs: good agricultural practices (through a demo), agrochemical use, post-harvest handling<\/li>
      3. To mitigate the challenge of counterfeit inputs, aggregate the needs for seeds and fertilizers \u2013 CGA will link with suppliers to get genuine inputs.<\/li>
      4. Set weighing standards to avoid issues of farmers selling at undetermined weights and consider selling as a group to avoid exploitation by the local traders.<\/li><\/ol>

        \u201cDuring the season assessment] it was very instructive to discuss with my members about our practices this season and we could see the economic impact of planting late or using minimum tillage and the number of fertilizer applications for example. We have agreed on some way forwards like aggregating demand for seeds and trying to do minimum tillage.\u201d Says Mary, Chairlady of NALEPO Women Group, Narok County.<\/p>

        Through this exercise, CGA was able to confirm the relevance of collecting farm technico-economic results and discussing them collectively as a group during season assessment in supporting farmers in the improvement of their farming system and thus their income.<\/p>

        NOTES:\u00a0<\/a>[1] Gross margin (GM) is the difference between the gross income and farm operation costs. It doesn\u2019t consider the fixed costs (depreciation, taxes, credit costs, etc.), which can be difficult to calculate and\/or neglectable for small scale farmers.\u00a0<\/a>[2] Cashflow is the total amount of cash available on the farm or at the household level. It is based on the difference between cash inflows and cash outflows.<\/p>","text_color":"#000000"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: Farm to Market Alliance (FtMA)
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
The Farm to Market Alliance (FtMA) is an initiative spearheaded by the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) through a consortium of end-to-end value chain actors comprising of the following global members: the Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA), RaboBank Group, Yara International, Syngenta and Bayer. The interventions under FtMA are aimed at unlocking crop value chains in order to enhance the participation of smallholder farmers through increasing their marketable surplus thereby improving their livelihoods.

The project is also been implemented in Zambia, Rwanda and Tanzania.

FtMA’s objective is to enable sustainable food systems through strengthen markets to empower farmers to increase their yields, income and resilience and to improve global food security. This will be achieved by creating an inclusive environment throughout the food value chain supported by appropriate policy and investment in hard and soft infrastructures. More on FtMA here

The following PILLARS guide FtMA operations:

  • Farmer Service Centre (FSC) Network Building.
  • Farmer Service Centre (FSC) Productivity Enhancing Services.
  • Farmer Service Centre (FSC) Market Linkage Services.
  • Farmer Digitization.

Geographical Coverage

Currently, the project is being implemented in the following Thirteen (13) counties:

  • Siaya
  • Kisumu
  • Nyandarua
  • Elgeyo Marakwet
  • Busia
  • Homabay
  • Narok
  • Migori
  • Tharaka Nithi
  • Meru
  • Kakamega
  • Nakuru
  • Bungoma

INITIAL PILOT COUNTIES:

Migori

Meru

TARGET VALUE CHAINS:

  • Maize
  • Sorghum
  • Beans
  • Soya
  • Rice
  • Potato
  • Finger Millet

item.title: Cereal Value Chain Development (CVCD) Project
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
This project is supported by French Development Agency (AFD) in partnership with Fert.  Fert is a French association for international cooperation for agricultural development in developing and emerging countries.

Geographical Coverage

  • Nakuru
  • Narok
  • Uasin Gishu as from 2019
  • Implementation period: 3 years (2018-2020).

The partnership focuses on improving cereal farmers’ income and livelihood with two specific objectives;

  • Improving membership services performance.

Strengthening Cereal Growers Association (CGA) as an apex farmers’ organization.

Target beneficiaries/partners – high potential commercial farmers including large scale, medium and small commercial farmers.

Target value chains : Maize, wheat, barley, sorghum and assorted pulses.

Further, CVCD has supported a study aimed at improving CGA’s service offering strategy.

item.title: CGA and AGRA Officialy Launch Phase II of The Regenerative Agriculture Program - A Scale Out
item.dc:creator: Joshua
item.content:encoded:
The project is funded by IKEA foundation through Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA). It is being implemented by Cereal Growers Association (CGA) and Farm Africa (FA) in 4 counties of Tharaka Nithi, Embu, Kitui and Makueni Counties. Cereal Growers Association (CGA) is implementing the project in Kitui and Makueni Counties while Farm Africa is implementing in Tharaka Nithi and Embu Counties. The project spans from May 15, 2022 to October 15, 2025.

The overall goal of the project is to contribute to the development of food and farming systems within a sustainable framework by employing regenerative, context-specific innovations and models, that appreciate local diversity to attaining climate-resilience and food security for smallholder farmers in Kenya.

The project aims to achieve three key outcomes outlined below:

  • Outcome 1: Context-specific, private sector business models for the development of circular, regenerative agriculture developed, validated, and shared
  • Outcome 2: The productivity of farms and landscapes enhanced by employing appropriate mix of regenerative agriculture and input delivery systems.
  • Outcome 3: The capacity of local and national governments in developing and/or enforcing policies in adoption and promotion of RA practices enhanced.

The project seeks to address five key challenges that small holder farmers in Makueni and Kitui counties are facing, namely: Adverse effects of climate change, land degradation, declining soil fertility, limited access to extension services and weak input and output market linkages which have resulted in low agricultural productivity. In both counties, the effects of climate change at the smallholder level have resulted in fragile semi-arid agro-ecological zones affecting existing farming activities in these ASAL counties that are dependent on rain-fed agriculture. These challenges hindering agricultural transformation in Makueni and Kitui counties require the smallholder farmers to adopt sustainable farming solutions such as regenerative agriculture, agroforestry, conservation agriculture and integrated soil fertility management technologies that incorporate the use of organic inputs and judicious use of site and crop-specific blended fertilizers.

CGA will promote the following sustainable farming practices in the two target counties: rehabilitation of degraded water catchments; good soil management practices to avert landslides and ﬂoods; forest cover through aﬀorestation, reaﬀorestation and agroforestry; species diversiﬁcation through planting of indigenous and exotic species; restoration of degraded soils and conservation of soil biodiversity through integrated soil fertility management (ISFM).

CGA will work with the village-based advisors (VBAs) to establish agroforestry nurseries with fodder tree crops e.g., Calliandra calothyrsus, Leucaena Spp. and Moringa oleifera trees which can supplement animal feed and Gliricidia sepium to support biomass production for green manure. Through kitchen gardening, CGA will target increased fruit and vegetable production and consumption at the household level.  Given the existing policy infrastructure in both counties to support improved extension services in the agriculture sector and majorly in Makueni county through the County Extension Volunteer programme (CEV), this proposed second phase of the Regenerative Agriculture (RA) project will seek to strengthen last mile delivery of extension services and enhance sustainability of extension service provision through the village-based Advisor (VBA) model.

This project “Building Regenerative, Sustainable and Profitable Smallholder Agricultural Transformative Systems in Kenya” provides an opportunity for AGRA and CGA to deepen its learning agenda in sustainable Regenerative Agriculture (RA) models and provide evidence to the wider sector for adoption at scale. The regenerative agriculture practices are in line with key agroecological principles as well as provide value adds for policy and institutional strengthening for sustainable production, farming, and consumption.

The project is an extension of a pilot project that was implemented in Embu and Makueni Counties between July 2020 and September 2021. It is therefore a scale out to Kitui and Tharaka Nithi counties and deep dive to the Makueni and Embu counties and it borrows to a greater extend on the lessons learnt during the pilot phase. The Kitui County targeted beneficiaries are 20, 000 farmers distributed in 4 Sub Counties, while in Makueni County, the project targets 30,000 smallholder farmers spread in 5 Sub Counties as shown in table (1) below.

Table 1: Project Implementation Areas

County Sub-County No. of Wards Name of Ward
Makueni Kaiti 4 Kee; Ilima; Kilungu; and Ukia
Makueni 7 Wote/Nziu; Mavindini; Kathonzweni; Muvau/Kikumini; Kitise/Kithuki; Zakika; and Mbitini
Kibwezi West 6 Emali/Mulala; Nguu/Masumba; Makindu; Nguumo, Kikumbulyu North; and Kikumbulyu South
Kibwezi East 3 Thange; Masongaleni; and Nzambani Ivingoni
Kilome 2 Kasikeu and Kiima Kiu
Kitui Kitui Rural 3 Yatta Kwa Vonza; Kanyangi; and Mbitini
Kitui East 3 Nzambani; Sombe/Mwitika; and Mutitu/Kaliku
Kitui West 4 Matinyani; Kaui; Kwa Mutonga; and Mutonguni
Kitui South 4 Athi; Ikutha; Ikanga/Kyatune; and Mutha

The project aligns with the Agriculture Sector Transformation and Growth Strategy (2019-2029 and the specific value chains in each ecological zone are specified below:

Table 2: Promoted Value Chains per Sub County in Kitui and Makueni Counties

County Sub-County Cereals Produced Pulses Produced
Makueni Makueni Maize (Upper areas); Sorghum (Kitise) Beans (HIB), Pigeon peas, Cow peas, and green grams
Kaiti Maize Beans (HI), Pigeon peas, Cow peas, and green grams
Kibwezi West Sorghum Pigeon peas, Cow peas, and green grams
Kibwezi East Sorghum Pigeon peas, Cow peas, and green grams
Kilome Sorghum Beans (HIB), Pigeon peas, Cow peas, and green grams
Kitui Kitui Rural Sorghum Pigeon peas, Cow peas, and green grams
Kitui East Sorghum Pigeon peas, Cow peas, and green grams
Kitui West Sorghum Pigeon peas, Cow peas, and green grams
Kitui South Sorghum Pigeon peas, Cow peas, and green grams

Through this project, CGA will reach 50,000 smallholder farmers directly through a network of 300 VBAs linked to over 50 private sector actors will participate in enhance knowledge, awareness, and adoption of these practices at the farm level. At the end of the project, it is expected that 70% of the targeted beneficiaries will adopt RA practices and over 6,000MT of pulses and 4,000MT of cereals will be produced, aggregated, and marketed (total value of produce sold € 4,018,634).

Through private sector linkages, over €1 million worth of inputs will be accessed by farmers. CGA expects 20-25% yield increases at the farm level owing to the adoption of RA practices. From a gender equity and youth inclusion view, CGA expects that at least 60% and 35% of women and youth will actively participate as VBAs.
